Situation1: They notice a mentee struggling with time management during casual check-ins.
Expectation2: Coordinate with other air traffic controllers to ensure smooth traffic flow
Situation2: Thunderstorm cells force multiple flights to reroute, increasing handoffs between sectors.
Story: The rain hammered the control tower windows as I scanned the radar, green and yellow blobs pulsing with every sweep. My headset crackled with voices—sector handoffs, reroute requests, pilots anxious about the storm. I was supposed to be the calm in the chaos, coordinating with my team, making sure every flight found a safe path. But my mind kept drifting to my mentee, Jamie. Just this morning, during our check-in, I’d noticed the dark circles under their eyes, the way they fumbled with their schedule. As a mentor, I should help Jamie find balance, encourage them to grow, not just survive. But now, as the storm intensified, the demands of the job pressed in. My team needed my full attention; one missed call could mean disaster. Yet, I couldn’t shake the urge to send Jamie a quick message, to offer support. The weight of both roles pressed on me—my responsibility to the skies, and to the person who looked up to me. My hands hovered over the console, torn between the demands of the moment and the promise I’d made to guide someone else.
